item.title: As Russians Retreat, Putin Is Criticized by Hawks Who Trumpeted His War
item.description: Russian bloggers reporting from the front line provide a uniquely less-censored view of the war. But as Russia’s military flails, these once vocal supporters are exposing its flaws, lies and all.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Juan Barreto/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A destroyed Russian military vehicle in Balakliya, in the eastern Kharkiv region, on Saturday.

item.title: ‘We can’t keep up’: People in Kyiv are glued to their phones, buoyed by the latest developments.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sandbags in central Kyiv on Sunday.

item.title: In Hasidic Enclaves, Failing Yeshivas Flush With Public Money
item.description: New York’s Hasidic Jewish religious schools have benefited from $1 billion in government funding in the last four years but are unaccountable to outside oversight.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro, Brian M. Rosenthal and Jonah Markowitz
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times

item.title: חסידישע מוסדות געבן נישט קיין עדיוקעשאן, אבער באקומען א שפע פון רעגירונגס געלטער
item.description: די חסידישע מוסדות אין ניו יארק האבן גענאסן פון 1 ביליאן דאלאר אין רעגירונגס געלטער דורכאויס די לעצטע פיר יאר אבער מוזן קיינעם נישט אפגעבן קיין דין וחשבון וואס מען לערנט ביי זיי
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro, Brian M. Rosenthal and Jonah Markowitz
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times

item.title: Share Your Stories About Hasidic Schools
item.description: The New York Times is researching Hasidic yeshivas. Tell us about your experiences.
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Central United Talmudical Academy spans an entire city block in Williamsburg. All its students who took state tests in 2019 failed. At a public school three blocks away, John Wayne Elementary, more than half of students passed.

item.title: With Queen Gone, Former Colonies Find a Moment to Rethink Lasting Ties
item.description: In Commonwealth nations with British colonial histories, Queen Elizabeth’s death is rekindling discussions about a more independent future.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Tim Graham Photo Library via Getty Images
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II in Tuvalu during a 1982 tour of the South Pacific, which also included a stop in the Solomon Islands.

item.title: A Slain Reporter, a City of Sin and a Politician Charged With Murder
item.description: As journalism and Las Vegas changed, Jeff German stayed true to his style: Build sources, chase leads, and leave nobody safe from accountability.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Mike Baker
item.media:credit: Bridget Bennett for The New York Times
item.media:description: The killing of Jeff German, a reporter for The Las Vegas Review-Journal, has rattled and outraged the readers, journalists and sources who had grown to trust his brand of shoe leather reporting.

item.title: Rise in Deaths Spurs Effort to Raise Alcohol Taxes
item.description: Alcohol taxes have been stagnant for years. But after the pandemic sent alcohol-related deaths soaring, activists in Oregon said higher taxes could save lives.
item.dc:creator: Ted Alcorn
item.media:credit: Celeste Noche for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sonja Grove lost her son, Jon, to an alcohol-related death two years ago.

item.title: How Book Bans Turned a Texas Town Upside Down
item.description: In a political environment where book-banning efforts are being used to drive voter sentiment, librarians find themselves on the front lines.
item.dc:creator: Erika Hayasaki

item.title: Carlos Alcaraz Is Favorite Against Casper Ruud in U.S. Open Men’s Singles Final
item.description: Sunday’s match is not only a battle for the U.S. Open men’s singles title. It will also determine the next world No. 1, and whoever wins will rise to the top spot for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times; Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Whoever wins will rise to the top spot for the first time: an unprecedented scenario in a major final since the ATP computer rankings were created in 1973.

item.title: Marking 9/11, Biden Remembers the ‘Precious Lives Stolen From Us’
item.description: Members of the Biden administration honored the victims of the attacks, which, 21 years later, remain deeply painful for the family members who lost loved ones.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Jeffery C. Mays
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden marked the anniversary by encouraging Americans to defend the nation’s democratic system.

item.title: Here Are Some of the Photographs of 9/11
item.description: Photographers reflect on shooting the terrorist attacks of 9/11 and their aftermath.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Krista Niles/The New York Times

item.title: Finding Peace on a River Float in Texas
item.description: From the center of an inner tube drifting down the slow-moving Guadalupe, in Texas, life looks good.
item.dc:creator: Shannon Sims
item.media:credit: Eli Durst for The New York Times
item.media:description: Float enthusiasts take to the river on a recent weekend, some with drinks tubes in tow.

item.title: With the Queen’s Death, Britain Must Let Go of Its Imperial Delusions
item.description: “There is no future in England’s dreaming,” warned the Sex Pistols.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kunzru
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Jack Taylor/Getty Images

item.title: Charles in Charge
item.description: No more women reign over the new king.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Bob Dear, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II followed by Princess Diana, the Princess of Wales and Prince Charles, the Prince of Wales, arrive for the State Opening of Parliament in London on Tuesday, Nov. 6, 1984.

item.title: All Biden Has to Do Now Is Change the Way We Live
item.description: The president’s legacy — and our climate future — will turn on what actually gets built, and how fast,
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 2022 Ford F-150 Lightning Electric truck in production at the Dearborn Truck Plant in Michigan.

item.title: Chile’s Constitutional Moment Is Not Over
item.description: An overwhelming vote to reject a new, progressive charter cannot stop Chileans from figuring out the future of their country.
item.dc:creator: Cristian Farias
item.media:credit: Martin Bernetti/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: With the blessing of Gabriel Boric, Chile’s president, the national Congress is already at work setting the parameters for how to start over on a new Constitution.

item.title: Rudy Giuliani Is Alone
item.description: 9/11 was his triumph, then it became his undoing.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Kirtzman
item.media:credit: Robert F. Bukaty/Associated Press
item.media:description: As mayor of New York, Rudolph Giuliani led Gov. George Pataki and Senator Hillary Clinton on a tour of the site of the World Trade Center the day after the Sept. 11 attack in 2001.

item.title: How to Argue Well
item.description: A former debating champion offers advice for our polarized moment.
item.dc:creator: Pamela Paul
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; image by rasslava via Getty Images

item.title: What We Pray for When We Pray for Our Children
item.description: How readers across the country pray with their families.
item.dc:creator: Tish Harrison Warren
item.media:credit: Matija Medved

item.title: The Ukraine War’s Decisive Season
item.description: We will soon see if European resolve holds up.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: Dimitar Dilkoff/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Britain’s Mourning Rituals
item.description: Britons are surrounded by visible symbols of Queen Elizabeth II’s death but relatively reserved in their grief.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prince William and his wife, Kate, with Prince Harry and Meghan yesterday.

item.title: The Sunday Read: ‘How the Claremont Institute Became a Nerve Center of the American Right’
item.description: It made the intellectual case for Trump. Now it believes the country is in a cultural civil war.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Zerofsky, Jack D’Isidoro, Elisheba Ittoop, John Woo, Dan Farrell and Quinton Kamara

item.title: This Fish Has a Smart Shortcut
item.description: Kay Chun uses peanut butter to create a simple, savory glaze.
item.dc:creator: Emily Weinstein
item.media:credit: Christopher Testani for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Monica Pierini.

item.title: Russell Wilson Spreads His Football Gospel to the Broncos
item.description: With a picture-perfect family, a Super Bowl-caliber team and Michael Jordan’s trainer at his side, the star quarterback is back to spreading football intensity — with a smile.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel
item.media:credit: Ron Chenoy/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: “I wasn’t just going to go anywhere,” Russell Wilson said of his trade to the Denver Broncos in March. “I felt like this team can be great.”

item.title: Fed’s Exit Puts World’s Biggest Bond Market on Shakier Ground
item.description: Some traders worry that the $25 trillion U.S. Treasury market is becoming more fragile, and the Federal Reserve’s removal of support could make it worse.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Market watchers are worried about a loss of liquidity as the Federal Reserve’s balance sheet shrinks.

item.title: Marsha Hunt, Actress Turned Activist, Is Dead at 104
item.description: She seemed well on her way to stardom until her career was derailed by the Hollywood blacklist. She then turned her attention to social causes.
item.dc:creator: Wendell Jamieson
item.media:credit: Associated Press Photo
item.media:description: The actress Marsha Hunt in an undated photo. Early in her career, she was one of the busiest and most versatile actresses in Hollywood.

item.title: ‘Glorious’ Hero or ‘Deplorable’ Traitor? Pétain’s Legacy Haunts French Island
item.description: Philippe Pétain, who led France to victory in World War I and then collaborated with the Nazis, is buried on a small island, where his grave is the site of bitter debates over his legacy.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times

item.title: Can you get reinfected with monkeypox?
item.description: Experts weigh in on how long immunity lasts after an infection — or vaccination.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images

item.title: Why Can’t I Stand the Sound of Chewing? Misophonia, Explained
item.description: Misophonia, a little-known syndrome, is characterized by strong negative emotional reactions to certain sounds or visual cues.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Guillem Casasús

item.title: We Want to Hear About Your Experience With Egg Freezing
item.description: The Times is looking for stories from readers.
item.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times

item.title: The Power of a Casual Check-in Text
item.description: New research says most of us underestimate the power of the casual check-in.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.category: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
item.media:credit: Moritz Wienert

item.title: If at First You Don’t Succeed at Love, Try an Instagram DM
item.description: When Carly Stein and Oliver Kremer matched on Hinge, they didn’t make it past the messaging stage before she ghosted. But he persisted.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Block
item.media:credit: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carly Stein and Oliver Kremer were married Aug. 28 in Berkeley, Calif. Mr. Kremer was especially nervous during the hora: “I thought I was going to fall off the front of the chair. But I held on for dear life and I survived,” he said.
